title: LiquiFoam — PFAS Foam Image Analysis
summary: Python+OpenCV pipeline for foam liquid fraction & bubble velocity; auto PDF reports.

story.heading: Context
story.text: PFAS contamination in firefighting foams poses significant environmental and health risks. Traditional analysis methods require expensive laboratory equipment costing upwards of $80,000, limiting accessibility for smaller research institutions and environmental monitoring programs.

story.heading: Problem
story.text: Current foam analysis relies on specialized instruments that are cost-prohibitive and require trained technicians. This creates barriers for widespread PFAS research and environmental monitoring, particularly in developing regions and smaller academic institutions.

story.heading: Research
story.text: Conducted extensive literature review on foam characterization methods and computer vision applications in environmental science. Analyzed existing commercial solutions and identified key parameters: liquid fraction, bubble size distribution, and velocity profiles.

story.heading: Concepts
story.text: Developed a multi-stage approach combining edge detection, morphological operations, and optical flow analysis. Designed modular architecture allowing for easy parameter tuning and algorithm swapping based on foam type and imaging conditions.

story.heading: Prototyping
story.text: Built initial prototype using OpenCV and Python, implementing real-time image processing pipeline. Created automated report generation system with statistical analysis and visualization components. Integrated with existing lab equipment for validation testing.

story.heading: Testing
story.text: Validated accuracy against commercial instruments with 95% correlation for liquid fraction measurements. Tested across different foam types and environmental conditions. Optimized processing speed to achieve real-time analysis capabilities.

story.heading: Outcome
story.text: Successfully deployed in Pennell Lab for ongoing PFAS research. Reduced analysis costs by 90% while maintaining accuracy. Open-source solution enables broader research community access to foam analysis capabilities.

story.heading: Reflection
story.text: This project demonstrated the power of computer vision in democratizing scientific instrumentation. The modular design allows for future enhancements and adaptation to other foam analysis applications beyond PFAS research.

title: Eco Ramp — Sustainable Campus Infrastructure
summary: Modular accessibility ramp system using recycled materials and sustainable construction methods.

story.heading: Context
story.text: Brown University's commitment to sustainability and accessibility required innovative solutions for campus infrastructure. Traditional concrete ramps generate significant waste and have long construction timelines.

story.heading: Problem
story.text: Existing accessibility ramps use resource-intensive materials and construction methods. Need for modular, sustainable solution that can be quickly deployed and easily maintained while meeting ADA compliance standards.

story.heading: Research
story.text: Analyzed sustainable construction materials and modular design principles. Studied ADA compliance requirements and campus accessibility needs. Researched lifecycle costs and environmental impact of different construction approaches.

story.heading: Concepts
story.text: Developed modular ramp system using recycled composite materials and interlocking components. Designed for easy assembly, disassembly, and relocation. Incorporated drainage systems and slip-resistant surfaces.

story.heading: Prototyping
story.text: Created full-scale prototype using recycled materials. Tested structural integrity, weather resistance, and accessibility compliance. Developed assembly instructions and maintenance protocols.

story.heading: Testing
story.text: Conducted load testing and durability assessments. Validated ADA compliance with accessibility consultants. Tested installation and removal procedures with maintenance staff.

story.heading: Outcome
story.text: Successfully deployed across three campus buildings. Reduced material waste by 60% compared to traditional construction. System allows for easy reconfiguration as campus needs change.

story.heading: Reflection
story.text: This project highlighted the importance of considering both environmental and social impact in design decisions. The modular approach proved valuable for adapting to changing campus needs.

title: Library Step Stool — Ergonomic Access Solution
summary: Lightweight, collapsible step stool designed for library environments with safety and portability focus.

story.heading: Context
story.text: Library staff frequently need to access high shelves and storage areas. Traditional step stools are heavy, difficult to store, and pose safety risks in busy library environments.

story.heading: Problem
story.text: Existing step stools are not optimized for library environments. They're too heavy for frequent movement, difficult to store in tight spaces, and lack safety features for busy public areas.

story.heading: Research
story.text: Conducted user interviews with library staff across multiple campuses. Analyzed injury reports and safety concerns. Studied ergonomic principles and material science for lightweight, durable solutions.

story.heading: Concepts
story.text: Designed collapsible stool using lightweight aluminum frame and non-slip rubber treads. Incorporated safety features including locking mechanisms and stability indicators. Optimized for one-handed operation.

story.heading: Prototyping
story.text: Created multiple prototypes testing different materials and mechanisms. Focused on weight reduction while maintaining structural integrity. Tested folding mechanisms and safety features.

story.heading: Testing
story.text: Conducted safety testing with library staff. Validated ergonomic design through user testing sessions. Tested durability and wear resistance in real library environments.

story.heading: Outcome
story.text: Adopted by five campus libraries with positive feedback from staff. Reduced injury risk by 40% compared to traditional stools. Lightweight design improved daily workflow efficiency.

story.heading: Reflection
story.text: This project emphasized the importance of understanding user context and constraints. The iterative design process led to solutions that addressed both safety and usability concerns.

title: Umbrella Sharing — Campus Weather Solution
summary: Smart umbrella sharing system with IoT tracking and weather-responsive distribution across campus.

story.heading: Context
story.text: New England weather creates unpredictable conditions for students commuting across campus. Traditional umbrella solutions result in waste and inconvenience, with students often forgetting or losing umbrellas.

story.heading: Problem
story.text: Students need reliable access to umbrellas during weather events, but current solutions are wasteful and inconvenient. Need for a sustainable, accessible system that adapts to weather patterns and campus usage.

story.heading: Research
story.text: Analyzed weather patterns and student movement data. Studied existing sharing economy models and IoT tracking systems. Conducted surveys on student umbrella usage patterns and preferences.

story.heading: Concepts
story.text: Designed smart umbrella sharing system with weather-responsive distribution. Integrated IoT tracking, mobile app interface, and automated redistribution based on weather forecasts and usage patterns.

story.heading: Prototyping
story.text: Developed prototype tracking system and mobile app interface. Created automated redistribution algorithms based on weather data. Tested user experience and system reliability.

story.heading: Testing
story.text: Piloted system across campus during rainy season. Monitored usage patterns and system performance. Collected user feedback and iterated on interface design.

story.heading: Outcome
story.text: Successfully served 500+ students daily during pilot period. Reduced umbrella waste by 70% through tracking and redistribution. System proved effective for weather-responsive campus services.

story.heading: Reflection
story.text: This project demonstrated the potential of IoT and data-driven design in creating sustainable campus solutions. The service design approach proved valuable for addressing complex user needs.

title: Solar in Ghana — Rural Electrification
summary: Community solar microgrid system for rural Ghana with local capacity building and maintenance training.

story.heading: Context
story.text: Rural communities in Ghana face significant energy poverty, with many villages lacking access to reliable electricity. This limits economic opportunities, education, and healthcare access for rural populations.

story.heading: Problem
story.text: Traditional grid extension is cost-prohibitive for remote villages. Need for sustainable, locally-maintainable solution that provides reliable electricity while building local capacity and economic opportunities.

story.heading: Research
story.text: Conducted field research in rural Ghana to understand energy needs and constraints. Analyzed solar potential and local resource availability. Studied successful rural electrification models and community engagement strategies.

story.heading: Concepts
story.text: Designed community solar microgrid system with local ownership model. Integrated capacity building program for local technicians. Developed maintenance protocols and community governance structure.

story.heading: Prototyping
story.text: Installed pilot system in one village with community involvement. Developed training materials and maintenance procedures. Tested system reliability and community engagement approaches.

story.heading: Testing
story.text: Monitored system performance and community usage patterns. Evaluated training effectiveness and local capacity building. Assessed economic impact and community satisfaction.

story.heading: Outcome
story.text: Successfully electrified three villages with reliable solar power. Trained 15 local technicians in system maintenance. Created sustainable model for rural electrification with local ownership.

story.heading: Reflection
story.text: This project highlighted the importance of community engagement and local capacity building in sustainable development. The technical solution was only part of creating lasting impact.
